comment_8:
Yes, the song is dark and morbid, but that's the kind of music I and a lot of people like to listen to sometimes. I understand that it's not for everyone, but it's fucking Eminem, what do you expect? People who say they hate this song have a right to their opinion, but if you don't like this kind of music, then you should know just from Eminem's reputation that you should not to listen to his music. Anyway, I prefer his darker songs like this one and "Stan", which I personally think are probably his two greatest songs, more than his more shallow songs (like "Ass Like That" for instance). I like that Eminem is willing to explore the ugly side of relationships and isn't afraid to put real people and sometimes real events and/or fantasties he's had into his songs. There's a real honesty in this song. You can sense that seething repressed anger. I like that raw emotion- you don't see that in a lot of modern music, especially in this genre. And it's so catchy too, despite how raw and open it is. 

I will say that I'm glad Eminem found an outlet for all his anger, but I don't think he'd be a homicidal maniac like some people seem to think if he hadn't found a way to let out his anger through his music. Or maybe he would. There is a fine like between madness and brillance after all. I think this song is brillant. Both the words and the music. The chorus is really catchy and pretty much explains how he's feeling and what he's thinking. "Bitch you did me so wrong, but I don't want to go on without you." 

3 hoorays for fucked up dysfuctional relationships!!!

Don't get me wrong, I'm an Eminem fan (I wouldnt be here if I wasn't), but I hate this song.

There's enough violence against women in this society, and it pisses me off to see him go and write this song and then be like, "I was just playin yall". It might be funny to him, but deep down inside it takes a really sick and mentally deficent person to write a song like this. Normal human beings do not think about cutting up their wife or ex-girlfreind or whatever and cutting them and their new lover and their son into pieces, putting them into a bag and tossing them in the ocean and then driving away with their kid... It's sick and little kids are gonna hear this crap and think that normal people are supposed to think like that, just cause Eminem did.

Eminem went WAY overboard with this, I mean it's one thing to have freedom of speech, but it's another thing to write a song like this just to create controversy, cause all it's gonna do is result in corrupting the shit out of little kids minds and make them think they are supposed to do this.


And I know all your arguements for this, "Oh kids shouldnt listen to Em's music", "Oh he was just playin"... whatever it is, this is sick music and I get really pissed at Eminem every time I hear someone I know say, "Oh that b**** is pissin you off, why dont you cut her into little pieces, I'll show you where the ocean's at".

That's my two cents, and if you dont like it... then post something :)

In response to, deep breath, ylimemi- Music clearly hasn't become lyric centred. Take, for an example, you- You don't consider rappers songwriters. This is ridiculous, and obvious either out of a) your own stereotypes of hip hop (which I'd rather not hear) or b) a predisposed dislike for the genre. And you are not meant to take Kim, nor most songs with a similar premise off his first album, seriously. The people on this site who make the sort of comments you do are the exact sort of people he was targeting- People who blow lyrics like this out of proportion.

Unfortunately, hip hop gets a bad rap nowadays because some, who are ill-informed, pass off hip hop based on their own stereotypes taken from the day's broadsheet. Please, people, cast whatever image off hip hop you have aside, and recognise that all this 'gun-toting gangstas' crap is a load of bollocks.

So too, is the stereotype of 'other people's music.' Yes, samples are used (for instance, the new non-hip-hop fan's darling Kanye West is a good example- most people who lambast hip hop for using samples adore the man, yet samples are the bread and butter of his work) but not always. The talented producer does not rely on them. 

And hip hop is a songwriter's genre. Yes, what you see on the muic channels and hear on the radio is usually bollocks, but that's the case with most genres of music- open your mind. Eminem's skills as a songwriter and rapper are underrated- By hip hop fans usually for the crime of either becoming commercially successful or nothing more than his heritage, and by rock fans for being a rapper who dares to intrude on mainstream radio. But, he is a talented rapper.

Don't cast judgments on the genre before you've listened to the better stuff.

comment_237:
Alright. I have read most of the comments, and have heard a range in comments, going from Eminem is a lunatic, to he's just fantasizing, and I figured I would insert my own. To begin with, there is a such thing as poetic license. Just as authors write out murder mystery's, and poets write out suicidal poems, or playwrights base tragedies on people they know, Eminem, I believe, has based this song on his wife. He may not even have considered beating his wife in any way, but instead, just wanted to put his hurt into a new light, escalating his own thoughts so that it was listened to carefully. He is the type I could picture doing something like that. Its called dramatizing. Anyone heard of it? 

Another thing, I have seen some people asking why he would of put down murdering his wife and child. HE DIDN'T. Read it again. Kim's boyfriend (who I believe she had married after divorcing Eminem) had a four year old son. He had murdered the boyfriend/husband, and the son came out, so he murdered him as well. He was planning on killing Kim and pinning the murder of the two on her, convincing the cops that she had murdered the two, then committed suicide. 

Sorry to say people, but too many have commented without actually reading the lyrics, or listening to the song. I hope this clears up any confusion, if there was any.

comment_295: Nothing new to say in the regard that this song is graphic, emotional-laced and controversial. To Eminem's talent, this is what great art does, provoke us. Not only will a song so graphic in description bring up the subject matter to further investigate/inquiry about, but it's also very therapeutic to listen to. Many songs we just LISTEN to, Some songs we just HEAR, and once in awhile, a song comes along that we can actually FEEL. This song you can FEEL, I personally can relate/empathize with Eminem. However, I also do understand that granted on our relationship experience, many might not be able to relate to the angst/pain that Eminem conveys so artistically and amazing in this song too. Another thing about this song that makes it unique, is that it's not really a rap song. And this isn't to say that Eminem isn't a rapper and that this song is a sell-out. I believe that this song bears testament to the greatness of Eminem as a talented artist and as a entertainer. I couldn't imagine no other artist coming close to recording a song so dark, direct and mesmerizing. And in regard to those people who feel the need to take these lyrics literally (as in the physical sense of harm they echo - or scream), and also those who confuse Eminem the artist, with Marshall the man, I'll just leave with this profound quote: Art is a lie that helps us realize the truth."-Pablo Picasso.
